												A decent enough casual game where the aim is to fire your balls at the approaching board so that you match three or more of the same colour ball, which causes any now unattached balls to fall off as well. The idea is to clear the board in as few moves as possible, but also against the clock - or rather the board, which moves down steadily (or fast if you haven't made any matches for a few seconds).There is an upgrade mechanism to give you skills you can use to get through awkward sections of the board, which rewards playing well in earlier rounds and getting low scores - you can get up to three upgrade points per board cleared, or as few as one if you take lots of shots to win. There is also some physics you can take advantage of (or get scuppered by), if a group of balls is only connected by one ball they will hang loose and swing around, sometimes banging into other groups, which can cause a chain reaction - or block off an area you wanted to be able to fire at next.Overall it is a decent enough game to play through if you like this sort of thing, don't expect anything new after the first level - each group of levels just adds another row of balls to clear, and each new zone adds one more colour to the mix to make things harder (but resets the depth of the game board to be much shorter again at first)

content:
Posted: April 18
												tl;dr: This is ABSOLUTELY worth two bucks.The thing about a casual puzzle game is that the gameplay matters so much more than the production values. Hellscape Games is clearly a very small studio (I'm betting a single person created this in his spare time), and Intergalactic Bubbles's strengths dovetail perfectly with that.The gameplay is excellent. Imagine Puzzle de Pon and a physics engine had a baby, and you've got the idea. You fire bubbles into an ever-advancing array, trying to match groups of three to remove them and clear the board. As pieces are removed, extra pieces retain their remaining connections to the main group, but can start to wiggle around quite a bit. This creates a wonderful emergent gameplay style that complements the main puzzle beautifully. It's a genuine rush to detach a group of bubbles and send them flying into a separate group, causing a chain reaction that destroys dozens of piece in one fell swoop. The tension of seeing a large group at the end of a long thin chain of pieces and desperately trying to break that section off is captivating and nail-biting.The pacing is... less than excellent. Hellscape has confused length with depth and that puts a big damper on the festivities. It would be a lot easier to go through 250 levels of very slowly increasing complexity if those levels were more carefully designed, rather than randomly generated. If the game had half as many levels, with upgrades costing half as much, it'd feel like much less of a slog. (Even better would be a simple, more customizable settings screen instead of an awkward list of levels, but that's a much bigger change.) As it stands, this is a game I play for about an hour every six months before I get bored.The production values aren't good. They get the job done, and do very little else. That said, this is a puzzle game; you don't come here for the graphics or the sound.All in all, I'd call this game a great idea, but unpolished. That said, its current sale price is two bucks, and it's absolutely worth that. It's a lot of fun, just in smaller doses than the game seems to encourage. Keep it installed on your system, and play it just a little once in a while. You'll have a great time.

												It's one of those 'shoot the bubble to pop other bubbles" games that you see a lot of on Facebook and on Mobile. You shoot 'Planets' instead of bubbles, and you also have 3 Abilities. There's an upgrade menu, where you spend 'Stars', which is a currency you earn by completing levels, to upgrade various passive and active skills. You know how on mobile puzzle games, when you complete a level it gives you a rating of 1 to 3 stars depending on how well you did? It's like that here, and also has the standard square grid level select too. Each level you can earn up to 3 stars, which are used to upgrade your shield, energy regeneration and other energy stuff(energy is used to use abilities), actually purchasing the 3 abilities(they're cheap), and passive upgrades where you can use the various abilities together.The 3 abilities are: "The Rocket", which basically throws the Planet above the others to land it somewhere further up, useful for when you want to drop a stack but can't reach it normally. The next ability is "The Wild", which is basically a multi-color Planet that can be matched with any other Planet. Then there's "The Bomb", which is like it sounds, you shoot it like a regular Planet and it destroys all Planets in a radius(that can be upgraded).I friggin' love this game. It's really fun and really cheap too. I definitely recommend it.

												An easy and nice game to spend a few hours with. Dynamics and tricks are quite simple and intuitive; background music and sounds are very nice. The special weapons and combinations added a new layer to an old-type game.PROs:- Commands and dynamics are really easy to grasp. You likely won't need the step-by-step introduction - but it's there, neverthless, if you need it.- Music and sounds. Like I said, they did a great job with it. Nothing is as viscerally satisfying as being able to get the whole table to explode with just one move.CONs:- The level of simplicity. Really, the whole game is almost too easy. You get almost at once the right, intuitive combination of exploding bubbles and special weapons needed to pass the harder levels. Conversely, the last sector is literally impossible to win with full stars and without special weapons; you'd need to try and try and try again until you get a lucky screen.- The colours. Blue, green and red, all right. But, add the yellow one to the mix and it gets really hard to pick them apart - and I'm not even vaguely color-blind. (And then comes the orange... no, really. There were moments when I had to stop and look at them a second time.)Going just by genre, I'd say 8/10. As a more general vote, a nice 7/10. I'll be likely re-playing this sometimes soon and I've already suggested it to other players.

												Intergalactic Bubbles is hardly an original game design; it's one of those simple games that get cloned ad nauseam, like Arcanoid or Tetris. Nevertheless, such clones are invariably entertaining because their core idea is so good, and if they manage to give it some nice twist, they can expect some real popularity.This is exactly what Intergalactic Bubbles does: by taking the concept of "put balls of the same colour together to make them disappear" and adding real physics, as well as some special moves and buyable upgrades, it provides a surprisingly good gaming experience. Yes, each level is virtually the same, but it's just this kind of game - it's pointless to expect anything else from it. It is what it is, and the repetitiveness is a feature like any other, not a shortcoming. What matter is that it's fun to shoot the balls, look for combinations, buy new skills and watch the balls swing quasi-realistically (hopefully with unexpected combos).The game has no major weak points, but the graphics aren't exactly pretty, which is a shame for this kind of game (especially visible on Steam cards, which I've melted to crystals as soon as possible before my eyes could bleed). I also have some reservations regarding balance of power-ups (for example, bomb costs more energy despite being less useful than multi-coloured ball), but it has very little impact on the actual gameplay.To sum up: Intergalactic Bubbles is a game for many, many evenings, but only if you don't mind doing the same thing over and over. But it never hurts to try, especially since the game is addictive as hell.

												I got this game because it seemed fun and simple; match three bubbles, get rid of bubbles, win. As I played it, I quickly realized that it was just that simple, yet somehow, so much more. I frothed, I raved, I swore. I was able to create inexplicable combinations, yet the most basic of shots elluded me. Perplexed, I vowed to never again feel that bitter sting of defeat. Not to these bubbles. And thus, I began to hone my skills.As I began to take this spiritual journey deep within the confines of that digital arena, egged on by soothing music reminiscent of puzzle games from my childhood, time seemed to slow. Nay, it seemed to halt for me alone. I could vaguely hear my family calling my cell phone, my boss to inquire of me as it had been three days of my absence, and it was unlike me. I could hear weeping, but was it myself, or the ones I loved?My family grew older, and larger, friends mourned for me, and yet I remained transfixed by this game, untouched by the hands of time. I lost my job yesterday, or was it perhaps ten years ago? The concept of hours, days, even years has become lost to me as I still hone myself, becoming a master of the bubbles. They called to me, speaking promises of glory and victory, and I refused to deny myself that which I so dearly desired. I would never bow to these colorful orbs as I had once in my youth. Youth? What did that even mean anymore? I have been here centuries now, unhindered by the pains of old age, frozen in my prime, learning the ways of the bubbles. Even death itself has forgotten me as I remain transfixed by this game. My family that I knew had passed on, leaving me alone, yet astoundingly without resentment; the woman they had known had been gone all of these millenia. And now, this very day, I stepped out of that plane of existance changed; born anew in the fires of reds, greens, and blues. My life as I had known it is forever gone, and I alone, save for the holy knowledge that the bubbles have bestowed upon me, remained. I shall go forth, and conquer. TLDR; Really addicting game. I totally recommend, but only if you are willing to lose your day to playing it.
